page.title: 17THE WATER TOWERS, PRENTON
page.content: On a low hill overlooking Prenton stand two water towers, visible above the surrounding deciduous and fir trees. One of the towers, no longer in use, is a circular steel tank with a conical roof, and this features on the badge of{Prenton Junior School. The other, a rectangular tower, is used to store water to supply{Prenton, {Oxton, Higher Bebington}and{Bidston. It holds over 2 million litres of water, and this is pumped to the tower from an underground reservoir on the same site, to provide a 'static head'. The reservoir, which holds over 7 million litres of water, is supplied from four{boreholes}drilled 203 metres into the red sandstone of the hill. The pumping station is driven by submersible electric pumps and is automatically controlled.
